report_title: Accidental Death & Dismemberment Insurance Industry Report
executive_summary: Improvements in underlying macroeconomic and demographic variables have outweighed subdued premium price growth for the AD&D Insurance industry over the five years to 2021. Industry operators primarily underwrite accidental death and dismemberment (AD&D) insurance policies. These policies pay out to a beneficiary upon the accidental death of the policyholder, or pay out to the policyholder directly in the case of accidents that cause a loss of limb or sight.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The AD&D Insurance industry revenue is anticipated to increase at an annualized 1.9% to reach $16.1 billion over the five years to 2021. However, the COVID-19 pandemic hurt the industry in 2020 due to a sharp rise in unemployment, reducing the pool of employees needing AD&D insurance. The industry managed to recover quickly in 2021, with industry revenue expected to rise 4.2% in 2021, driven by an increase in total employment, per capita disposable income, and strong investment returns for operators.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Over the five years to 2026, industry revenue is forecast to increase at an annualized 1.4% to $17.2 billion as the economy rebounds from the coronavirus outbreak.
Macroeconomic and demographic trends, such as per capita disposable income levels and the median age of the population, are anticipated to consistently boost industry policy volumes.
However, the industry's close relationship with the broader Life Insurance and Annuities industry could bring additional regulatory scrutiny, particularly with respect to reinsurance activities.

During this period, equity market growth is expected to temper, while competition amongst industry operators is expected to intensify, leading industry profit margins (measured as earnings before interest and taxes) to decline to 16.3% of revenue over the five years to 2026.

industry_definition: This industry underwrites (i.e. assumes the risk and assigns premiums for) accidental death and dismemberment (AD&D) insurance policies. AD&D policies pay out money to a beneficiary upon the accidental death of the policyholder. In the case of accidents that cause a loss of limb or sight, AD&D policies pay out to the policyholder directly.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Consumers in this demographic have largely tempered the industry's revenue fluctuations caused by declining policy volumes in other age demographics and volatility in investment gains. Individuals in this age group not only tend to have higher disposable income levels, but also typically have dependents that would benefit from the insured's AD&D policy in the event of accidental death or dismemberment.

Individuals aged 65 and older are anticipated to account for 24.0% of total industry revenue in 2021. Despite largely being in retirement and out of the labor force, these individuals remain key buyers of insurance products, including life insurance and AD&D policies. Moreover, given the continued aging of the domestic population, this age demographic has account for an increasing share of industry premiums over the current five-year period.

Consumers are the ultimate market for the AD&D Insurance industry, paying premiums to ensure benefit payments in the event of accidental death or dismemberment. In 2021, individuals aged 34 and younger are anticipated to account for 18.5% of total industry revenue. Both overall life insurance and AD&D insurance have low levels of penetration in this demographic due to its lower average income, assets, employment rates and number of dependents.

products_and_services.product_description: Employers purchase industry products in the group life supplement segment. In the event of a qualifying accidental death, this product pays an amount equal to a life insurance payout to the insured's designated recipient. Furthermore, this product offers a percentage of the full accidental death payout, which is payable upon an event occurring that qualifies as dismemberment. Dismemberment includes, but is not limited to, the loss of appendages, digits, hearing and sight.

Voluntary accidental death and dismemberment (AD&D) coverage is offered as either a supplemental product to life insurance or as a stand-alone service. Voluntary AD&D as a stand-alone insurance plan is paid for by the individual subscribing to it. This type of insurance can be purchased regardless of the insured's enrollment in a life insurance plan. Supplemental AD&D coverage is offered in conjunction with a subscribers' life insurance plan and is paid for by the individual subscriber. This type of product typically provides the same benefit as the insured's life insurance. Both supplemental and stand-alone AD&D offer a percentage of the death payout for qualifying dismemberment injuries that do not result in death. Dismemberment is defined differently by various institutions, but generally covers the loss of limbs, hearing, eyesight and digits.

Dependent AD&D insurance coverage offers coverage extension to the insured's dependents. Dependent AD&D coverage is predominately employee-paid and provides spouses and dependents with benefit payments.

An employee or his or her employer can pay for travel accident coverage. This type of AD&D insurance pays out for qualifying accidents that occur while traveling and also offers fringe benefits. Such perks include concierge assistance, which provides a multitude of services, both personal and professional. Moreover, these policies can also include entertainment requests and arrangements for business related services.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Rising disposable income levels are correlated with increased policy volumes, as downstream consumers have the enhanced ability to afford policy premiums. Moreover, increased disposable income levels also increase a potential client's standard of living, something AD&D insurance policies can protect in the event of accidental dismemberment.

The aggregate number of employees is also a crucial demand determinant for industry operators. While consumers are the ultimate market for AD&D policies, industry products are frequently purchased through group plans.

Trends involving the median age of the population and the number of accidents also affect industry demand. An increasing average age for the industry is beneficial, given that the majority of the industry's revenue is garnered from consumers aged 35 to 64; these individuals have higher disposable income levels and more dependents that would benefit from AD&D benefit payments. Similarly, an increasing number of accidents or unintentional injuries, as measured by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, also tends to boost demand for the industry, given the increased expected value that AD&D policies provide.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Given the service-based nature of the AD&D Insurance industry, exports and imports are not applicable. While the majority of operators are domestically owned, a growing portion of insurers is focusing on international markets for additional distribution opportunities.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Insurers are highly regulated at the state level, with laws establishing agencies with broad authority over licensing, rates, reserves, capital, investments, etc.
The NAIC introduced RBC requirements in 1993 to determine the levels of capital an insurer must maintain based on its risks, with different levels of regulatory action.
Insurance departments conduct detailed examinations of insurers' books every 3-5 years as part of routine oversight.
Insurers must use the conservative SAP accounting system defined by state law when filing reports with regulators, differing from standard GAAP.

barriers_points.barrier_description: A prospective entrant must first raise capital to run operations and meet state capital requirements.
New enterprises must build a distribution network that uses both in-house and independent agents and brokers to sell their products.
The business must also hire highly trained actuaries and underwriters who are capable of competitively pricing policies and minimizing risks.
The industry is subject to stringent regulations, particularly at the state level.

basis_points.basis_description: The majority of AD&D insurance products are similar in nature, making it crucial for industry operators to compete on the basis of price.
Industry operators also compete on the basis of service quality and product range.
The capital position of an insurer represents another crucial basis of competition. The extent of an operator's reserves dictates its ability to take on additional risk and expand in the industry.

concentration_points.concentration_description: In 2021, the industry's four largest companies are expected to account for just 16.2% of industry revenue.
The level of concentration within the industry has decreased slightly in recent years, due to sector wide consolidation through merger and acquisition activity.
Larger, better-established operators generally outperform smaller or entry-level players due to established reputations, product offerings, capital and ability to attract talent.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The largest expense for the insurance sector, benefit payments are anticipated to account for more than 50.0% of total revenue for the AD&D Insurance industry in 2021.

Additions to policy reserves also account for a large of portion of industry revenue. In the insurance sector, reserves are funds held by an insurer to ensure the payment of future policyholder benefits.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: IBISWorld estimates that for every $1.00 spent on wages, the industry will allocate $0.04 to capital investment in 2021.

To provide AD&D insurance, industry operators need to employ highly educated and skilled workers including skilled underwriters, in-house sales teams, back-office support personnel and other operational employees.

Industry operators benefit from economies of scale with respect to capital investment as technological expenses related to policy administration and actuarial activities generally do not incrementally increase when policy volumes rise.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Fluctuations in premiums and investment returns
volatility_points.volatility_description: Volatility primarily depends on any aggregate changes in premiums and policy volumes, in addition to fluctuations in investment returns.

The COVID-19 pandemic introduced significant volatility, with industry revenue contracting 1.9% in 2020 due to declines in employment and consumer confidence, but projected to grow 4.2% in 2021 as economic activity resumed.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Human capital is needed to appropriately model certain risks associated with underwriting policies, insulating the industry from technological competition.
The industry requires information technology to maintain customer data, process transactions, manage risks and sales processes. Cybersecurity has been a focus for large insurers.
The broader insurance industry is expected to expand use of advanced analytics, data, and mobile applications to improve operations and client satisfaction.

FAQs.question: How do you emphasize the value of your company's services?
FAQs.answer: AD&D insurers market the value of the line of insurance as a supplemental line to customers existing insurance coverage.

FAQs.question: How diversified are your product offerings compared to competitors?
FAQs.answer: AD&D insurers offer homogeneous products, making price differentiation vital to operators.

FAQs.question: Does your company have exposure to fintech competitors? How is it affecting your strategy moving forward?
FAQs.answer: AD&D insurers face little to no competition from fintech competitors.

FAQs.question: What international operations do you conduct and how could benefit from increasing your international reach?
FAQs.answer: AD&D insurers tend to conduct next to no business internationally for regulatory reasons.

FAQs.question: How have you taken advantage of rising internet and mobile-internet penetration into the financial services industry?
FAQs.answer: Since AD&D insurance is by and large provided by businesses to workers, internet penetration has little effect on demand for the insurance.

FAQs.question: To what extent are your processes automated and how do you plan on investing in automation over the coming years?
FAQs.answer: The underwriting of AD&D insurance is labor-intensive leading little of the process to be automated.

FAQs.question: How do you expect the proposed changes to Dodd-Frank to affect your business?
FAQs.answer: AD&D insurers are likely to face increased regulatory scrutiny from the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, which was created out of Dodd-Frank.

FAQs.question: How have the increased capital requirements under Basel III affected operations?
FAQs.answer: AD&D insurers are not affected by Basel III, as they are not lenders.

FAQs.question: To what extent are you affected by hard and soft pricing cycles?
FAQs.answer: AD&D insurance is far less susceptible to pricing cycles than other lines of insurance.

FAQs.question: How does your profit margin compare to those of your competitors?
FAQs.answer: AD&D insurers profit margins mainly vary on the types of businesses and individuals they provide services to.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure it remains in a strong financial position? What are some ways you can improve?
FAQs.answer: AD&D insurers must maintain adequate capital to ensure compliance with prudential regulations. A strong capital position is also important for expanding operations.

FAQs.question: What is your biggest cost for the company?
How far-reaching is your business, geographically speaking? Do you have franchises or remote brokers with whom you coordinate?
FAQs.answer: AD&D insurers must have an extensive distribution network so they can provide services to customers in all geographic areas. This can be achieved through the use of agents, brokers, online resources and retail stores.

FAQs.question: How do you determine the profitability of the companies that sponsor retirement plans? What measure do you have in place to mitigate future falls in profit?
FAQs.answer: AD&D insurers must effectively manage their asset portfolios to ensure adequate returns while also minimizing risk. As a result, the majority of the industry's assets are in fixed income products.

FAQs.question: How many of the claims you process are about work-related deaths? How can you improve your processing systems?
FAQs.answer: Increases in the number of work-related deaths tends to signify that a higher percentage of the labor force is working in dangerous industries. Workers in such industries tend to be most likely to purchase AD&D insurance.

FAQs.question: How does demand for your services correlate with the performance of the S&P 500 index and other measures of stock market performance?
FAQs.answer: While the industry invests the majority of its assets in bonds, an estimated 30.0% of total assets are anticipated to be related to equity markets. As a result, stock market gains also benefit industry investment returns and revenue significantly.

FAQs.question: In which industries do your members participate? How do you monitor employment trends in these industries?
FAQs.answer: As industry products are frequently purchased through group plans, rising employment levels directly increase the probability of additional group AD&D premiums. Moreover, rising employment levels also tend to indirectly boost consumer wealth and the ability for additional clients to take on AD&D coverage.
